item.title: Happy 20th Birthday MinnuğŸ‰â¤ï¸
item.description:
For Srirenjini ğŸŒŸ

A Small Note from [MSK]

Throwback to Our Plus Two Days ğŸ’

  • Prethyekich parayan onnulla, but it was a great time during the plus two and following, Ini bhakki AI paranjolum

  • The Friendship Upgrade ğŸš€:

    • You tolerated my terrible Biology jokes.
    • I survived your “Iâ€™ll-only-study-the-night-before” chaos (and secretly admired your confidence).

The 18th Birthday Portrait Debacle ğŸ¨

Letâ€™s revisit this:

  • The “Art”: A portrait so bad, it made stick figures look like Da Vinci.
  • The Truth: I knew it was terribleâ€¦ but you smiled anyway. That meant everything.
  • The Real Gift: You taught me friendship isnâ€™t about perfectionâ€”itâ€™s about showing up, even when you suck at drawing. ğŸ™Œ

Where We Are Now ğŸŒ

  • You: Future Dr. Srirenjini, saving lives in Kozhikode ğŸ©ºâœ¨.
  • Me: Still Figuring out should I start business or should I leave my house, still drawing questionable art ğŸ–ï¸ (but slightly better houses now!).
  • What I Miss:
    • Your laugh when I tried to explain quantum physics using “vibes”.
    • The way youâ€™d say “Stop overthinking!"â€¦ while we both overthought everything.

No Pressure, Just Gratitude ğŸ’Œ

  • Why Iâ€™m Writing This:
    • To say thank you for being the kind of friend who treasures terrible portraits.
    • To remind you that even if we talk once a year, Iâ€™ll always cheer for you. ğŸ¥¤ğŸ“£
  • No Strings Attached, but if you ever want to:
    • Swap MBBS stories for my depression stories and other disappointments, Im all ears.
    • Judge my “improved” art (spoiler: now with 10% fewer blobs).
    • Reminisce about the way you took you stance as a Kathakali when you tried to skip a rock through the water at Munnar, and the memories of you talking with me just brings me good mindfulness when i think.

A Tiny Wish ğŸŒ™

May your stethoscope always hear good news, your coffee stay strong, and your heart never forget the goofy friend who still owes you a better portrait. ğŸ–¼ï¸

The Rickshaw Ride That Changed Everything

During high school, my teacher shared the story of Irfan Alam and his SammaaN Foundation. It was a moment that stayed with me:

“Solutions hide in plain sightâ€”true change begins when we see dignity in struggle and potential in ordinary moments.”

My multidisciplinary backgroundâ€”from hospitality to computer scienceâ€”fuels my belief in versatile problem-solving. Iâ€™m driven to leverage technology for sustainable, community-focused solutions.
